snippet.title: HIV: Philippines has highest infection rate in Asia-Pacific, United Nations says
snippet.content:
The Philippines has recorded the fastest-growing HIV/AIDS epidemic in the Asia-Pacific in the past six years with a 140 per cent increase in new infections, the Health Ministry and United Nations have said.
Key points:
10,500 Filipinos were infected with HIV at the end of 2016 Health Ministry encourages voluntary HIV testing Most new infections were among young men
There were 10,500 Filipinos infected with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) at the end of 2016, up from 4,300 in 2010, Health Minister Paulyn Ubial told a media conference, citing data from UNAIDS. Ms Ubial encouraged voluntary HIV-testing and use of condoms to help fight the problem, which in May 2017 alone saw 1,098 new cases of HIV infections in the Philippines, the highest recorded number of cases since 1984, when infections were first reported. The country could still end the public health threat by 2030 if the Government could redirect its focus on the people and locations most at risk, said Eamonn Murphy, UNAIDS regional support team director for Asia-Pacific. He said 83 per cent of new HIV cases occurred among males who have sex with males and transgender women who have sex with males. Genesis Samonte, head of the Health Ministry's public health surveillance department, said men who have sex with men were most at risk. "We're not talking about those that are openly gay," Ms Samonte said. "Any male who has sex with another male for whatever reason, is at risk." Two out of three new HIV infections were among 15 to 24 year-old men, who she said had insufficient awareness of HIV, its symptoms and treatment. Most of the men had their first sexual encounter at 16 years old and only get tested for HIV eight years later, she said. Reuters
